{{For|the structure|House}}
{{For|houses for animals|Habitat}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}}
[[File:SearsHouse115.jpg|thumb|300px|Plans for a detached [[house]] showing the social functions for each room]]

A '''home''' or '''domicile''' is a dwelling-place used as a permanent or semi-permanent residence for an individual, [[family]], [[household]] or [[Longhouse|several families in a tribe]]. It is often a [[house]], [[apartment]], or other [[building]], or alternatively a [[mobile home]], [[houseboat]], [[yurt]] or any other portable shelter. A principle of [[constitutional law]] in many countries, related to the [[right to privacy]] enshrined in article 12 of the UN Declaration of Human Rights<ref>http://www.ohchr.org/EN/UDHR/Documents/UDHR_Translations/eng.pdf</ref> is the inviolability of the home as an individual's [[Shelter (building)|place of shelter and refuge]].

Homes typically provide areas and facilities for sleeping, preparing food, eating and hygiene. Larger groups may live in a [[nursing home]], [[Orphanage|children's home]], [[convent]] or any similar institution. A [[Homestead (buildings)|homestead]] also includes agricultural land and facilities for [[domesticated animals]]. Where more secure [[dwelling]]s are not available, people may live in the informal and sometimes illegal [[shack]]s found in [[slums]] and [[shanty town]]s. More generally, "home" may be considered to be a geographic area, such as a [[town]], [[village]], [[suburb]], [[city]], or [[country]].

Transitory accommodation in a treatment facility for a few weeks is not normally considered permanent enough to replace a more stable location as 'home'.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} In 2005, 100 million people worldwide were estimated to be [[homelessness|homeless]].

==History==
{{expand section|date=November 2013}}
Buildings such as [[Hut (dwelling)|huts]] and [[longhouse]]s have been used for living since the late [[Neolithic]].<ref name="Skara Brae">{{cite web | url=http://www.orkneyjar.com/history/skarabrae/ | title=Skara Brae | publisher=Orkneyjar | accessdate=8 December 2012}}</ref>

It is unknown when the first mansion was built because there is no way to know for sure, but it is believed to have origins as a type of palace during the Mesopotamian period.<ref name="Quora.com">{{cite web | url=https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-first-mansion-ever-built-on-the-entire-globe | title=What is the first mansion ever built on the entire globe? | publisher= Austin Bennett | accessdate=12 December 2017}}</ref>

==Types==
{{expand section|date=July 2015}}
{{further|List of human habitation forms}}

===Buildings===
[[File:Hancock-homestead-settler.jpg|thumb|1910 American homestead]]
A [[house]] is a [[building]] that functions as a home for [[human]]s <ref>American Shelter: An Illustrated Encyclopedia of the American Home By Les Walker. Overlook Press, 1 July 1998</ref> ranging from simple [[dwelling]]s such as rudimentary huts of [[nomadic tribes]] to complex, fixed structures of wood, brick, or other materials containing plumbing, ventilation and electrical systems.<ref name=schoenauer>Schoenauer, Norbert (2000). ''6,000 Years of Housing'' (rev. ed.) (New York: W.W. Norton & Company).</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://clerk.house.gov/member_info/TTD-113.pdf|title=housing papers|publisher=clerk.house.gov|date= |accessdate=18 December 2012}}</ref> Most conventional modern houses will at least contain a [[bedroom]], [[bathroom]], [[kitchen]] or cooking area, and a [[living room]]. In traditional agriculture-oriented societies, [[List of domesticated animals|domestic animals]] such as chickens or larger livestock (like cattle) may share part of the house with humans. The social unit that lives in a house is known as a [[household]]. Most commonly, a household is a [[family]] unit of some kind, although households may also be other [[Group (sociology)|social groups]] or individuals. The design and structure of homes is also subject to change as a consequence of globalization, urbanization and other social, economic, demographic, and technological reasons. Various other cultural factors also influence the building style and patterns of domestic space.

A [[terraced house]]{{efn|also known as a terrace house ([[British English|UK]]), townhouse ([[American English|US]]), row houses or linked houses}} is a style of [[medium-density housing]] where a row of identical or mirror-image houses share side walls, while [[semi-detached]] housing consists of pairs of houses built side-by-side or (less commonly) back-to-back,<ref>https://www.ura.gov.sg/circulars/text/dchbr/pt1landedhousing-dchbr.pdf</ref> sharing a [[party wall]] and with mirrored layouts.

An [[apartment]] (in [[Comparison of American and British English#Levels of buildings|American English]]) or a flat (in [[British English]]) is a self-contained housing unit (a type of residential [[real estate]]) that occupies only part of a [[building]]. Such a building may be called an ''apartment building'', ''apartment house'' (in American English), ''block of flats'', ''[[tower block]]'', ''high-rise'' or, occasionally ''mansion block'' (in British English), especially if it consists of many apartments for [[Renting|rent]]. In Scotland it is called a block of flats or if it's a traditional sandstone building a ''tenement'', which has a pejorative connotation elsewhere. Apartments may be owned by an ''owner/occupier'' by leasehold tenure or rented by ''tenants'' (two types of [[housing tenure]]).

A [[Homestead (buildings)|homestead]] consists of a [[dwelling]], often a [[farm house]], together with other buildings and associated land, and facilities for [[domesticated animals]].

==Occupants==
{{expand section|date=July 2015}}
{{further|Household|Roommate}}
A home's occupants may be a single [[person|individual]], a [[family]], [[household]], or [[Longhouse|several families in a tribe]]. Occupants may be part of other groups, such as nursing home residents or children in an orphanage.

==Tenure==
{{expand section|date=July 2015}}
{{main|Housing tenure}}
The financial arrangements under which someone has the right to live in a home are, most frequently, [[leasehold estate|tenancy]], in which [[renting|rent]] is paid by the tenant to a [[landlord]], and [[owner-occupancy]].  Mixed forms of tenure are also possible.

===Owner-occupancy===
{{further|Owner-occupancy}}

===Rental accommodation===
{{further|Renting}}

===Squatting===
{{main|Squatting}}
Squatting is an action of occupying an abandoned or unoccupied area of land or a [[building]] – usually residential<ref>{{Citation |first=Chris |last=Roberts |title=Heavy Words Lightly Thrown: The Reason Behind Rhyme |publisher=Thorndike Press |year=2006 |isbn=0-7862-8517-6 }}</ref>  – that the 'squatter does not [[Land ownership and tenure|own, rent or otherwise have lawful permission to use]].

==Homelessness==
{{main|homelessness}}
[[File:Street dwellers in San'ya district in Tokyo Japan.jpg|thumb|Homeless people in [[San'ya]] district, [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]]]]

Article 25 of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]], adopted in 1948 contains the following text regarding housing and quality of living: "''Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well-being of himself and of his family, including food, clothing, housing and medical care and necessary social services...''"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/en/documents/udhr/index.shtml#a25 |title=Article 25 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights|date= 10 December 1948|publisher=United Nations }}</ref>

In 2004, the [[United Nations]], Department of Economic and Social Affairs, defined a homeless [[household]] as "''those households without a shelter that would fall within the scope of living quarters. They carry their few possessions with them, sleeping in the streets, in doorways or on piers, or in another space, on a more or less random basis.''"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/demographic/products/dyb/techreport/hhChar.pdf|title=United Nations Demographic Yearbook review: National reporting of household characteristics, living arrangements, and homeless households : Implications for international recommendations|publisher=United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, Statistics Division, Demographic and Social Statistics Branch|date=14 April 2004}}</ref>

In 2009, at the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe Conference of European Statisticians recommended that homeless people are classified in two broad groups (noting that this would not provide a complete definition):<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/censuskb20/Attachments/2009MPHASIS_ECE_Homeless-GUID25ae612721cc4c2c87b536892e1ed1e1.pdf|title=Enumeration of Homeless People|work=United Nations Economic and Social Council|date=18 August 2009|publisher=Economic Commission for Europe Conference of European Statisticians}}</ref>
*(a) Primary homelessness (or rooflessness). This category includes persons living in the streets without a shelter that would fall within the scope of living quarters.
*(b) Secondary homelessness. This category may include persons with no place of usual residence who move frequently between various types of accommodations (including dwellings, shelters, and institutions for the homeless or other living quarters). This category includes persons living in private dwellings but reporting ‘no usual address’ on their census form.

In 2005, 100 million people worldwide were estimated to be [[homelessness|homeless]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/bigpicture/2011/12/homelessness_around_the_world.html|title=Homelessness around the world|work=Boston Globe|date=14 December 2011}}</ref> although some prefer the term 'houseless' or 'unsheltered'.

==Psychological significance==
A home is generally a place that is close to the heart of the owner, and can become a prized possession. It has been argued that psychologically "''The strongest sense of home commonly coincides geographically with a dwelling. Usually, the sense of home attenuates as one moves away from that point, but it does not do so in a fixed or regular way.''"<ref>{{cite journal|author=Terkenli, T. S.|year= 1995|title=Home as a Region|journal=Geographical Review|volume= 85|issue=3|pages= 324–334|jstor=215276}}</ref> Since it can be said that humans are generally creatures of [[Habituation|habit]], the state of a person's home has been known to physiologically influence their [[behavior]], [[emotion]]s, and overall [[mental health]].<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sb9qa2gKeREC&pg=PA35 |title=Raising Young Refugees' Voices in Europe and Beyond |author1=Boutruche, Samuel |author2=Bourgeois, Stéphanie |author3=Lyamouri-Bajja, Nadine |publisher=[[Council of Europe]] |year=2008 |page=35|isbn=9789287163080 }}</ref><!--Source does mention WP, but separately provides independent evidence--> People may become [[Homesickness|homesick]] when they leave their home over an extended period of time. Places like homes can trigger self-reflection, thoughts about who someone is or used to be or who they might become.{{citation needed|date=November 2013}}<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://warwick.ac.uk/services/counselling/informationpages/homesickness/|title=Homesickness - Settling in to University|last=Haywood|first=Trudy|date=27 July 2017|website=Warwick|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> These types of reflections also occur in places where there is a collective historical identity, such as [[Battle of Gettysburg|Gettysburg]] or [[Ground Zero]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Burton-Christie, Douglas |year=2009|title=Place-Making as Contemplative Practice|journal=[[Anglican Theological Review]] |volume=91|issue=3|pages= 347–371|url=http://www.anglicantheologicalreview.org/read/article/1006/}}</ref>

Popular [[sayings]] include  "''a man's home is his castle''",<ref>[http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWCA/Civ/2013/798.html Malik v Fassenfelt & Others] [2013] EWCA Civ 798 (Court of Appeal of England and Wales) His Honour Sir [[Alan Ward (judge)]] began the panel's appellate judgment "The idea that an Englishman's home is his castle is firmly embedded in English folklore and it finds its counterpart in the common law of the realm..."</ref> "''there is no place like home''", "''home sweet home''", "''to be at home''", "''home away from home''", "''make yourself at home''", "''you can never go home again''",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://idioms.thefreedictionary.com/home|title=Home|work=idioms.thefreedictionary.com}}</ref> "''home is where the heart is''"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://idioms.thefreedictionary.com/Home+is+where+the+heart+is |title=Home is where the heart is |accessdate=4 December 2012}}</ref> and "''home is where you hang your hat''".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usingenglish.com/reference/idioms/home+is+where+you+lay+your+hat.html |title=Idiom: Home is where you lay your hat |accessdate=4 December 2012}}</ref>

The word ''home'' can be used for various types of residential community [[institution]]s in which people can live, such as [[nursing home|nursing]], [[retirement home]]s for seniors, [[foster home]]s, etc.{{citation needed|date=November 2013}} Short-term accommodation in a treatment facility for several weeks is unlikely to be considered 'home'.

Homes may be lost in ways ranging from the upheavals of [[natural disaster]]s<ref>{{cite news|last=Teves, Hranjski|first=Oliver, Hrvoje|title=Death toll from Philippine typhoon climbs past 500|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2012/12/07/death-toll-philippine-typhoon-500/1752981/|work=USA Today|accessdate=8 December 2012|date=7 December 2012}}</ref>, fraud/theft, [[arson]], or war-related destruction, to the more common voluntary sale, loss for one or more occupants on relationship breakdown, [[eminent domain|expropriation]] by government or legislated cause, repossession/[[foreclosure]] to pay secured debts, [[eviction]] by landlords, disposal by time-limited means – [[lease]], or absolute gift.  Jurisdiction-dependent means of home loss include [[adverse possession]], unpaid [[property taxation]] and corruption such as in circumstances of a [[failed state]].  [[Personal insolvency]], development or sustaining of [[mental disorder|mental illness]] or severe physical incapacity without affordable [[care work|domestic care]] commonly lead to a change of home.  The underlying character of a home may be debased by [[Structural integrity and failure|structural defects]], natural [[subsidence]], [[property maintenance|neglect]] or [[soil contamination]].  [[Refugee]]s from homes flee where such extreme forms of quasi-nuisance occur such as [[harassment]] and [[religious persecution]], who may seek a [[sheltered housing]] refuge or [[right of asylum|place of asylum]] respectively.
